thread.title: Labour's Brexit chaos deepens as 17 frontbenchers defy Jeremy Corbyn
thread.title_full: Labour's Brexit chaos deepens as 17 frontbenchers defy Jeremy Corbyn

author: Kate McCann
title: Labour's Brexit chaos deepens as 17 frontbenchers defy Jeremy Corbyn
text:
Labour's Brexit chaos deepens as 17 frontbenchers defy Jeremy Corbyn Watch | MPs vote to back triggering Article 50 00:33 Kate McCann , Senior Political Correspondent 1 February 2017 • 10:12pm 
L abour’s chaos over Brexit deepened after 17 frontbenchers defied Jeremy Corbyn’s orders and voted against legislation to trigger leaving the EU . 
The Labour leader is facing the prospect of his third reshuffle in 18 months after four shadow ministers quit before the vote and a further 13 front-bench members rebelled. Now the battle of the week ahead is to shape Brexit negotiations to put jobs, living standards and accountability centre stage Jeremy Corbyn 
O ne in four Labour MPs – 47 in total – defied a three-line whip. There were suggestions that the 13 shadow ministers who voted against Brexit may avoid disciplinary action. 
Diane Abbott, the shadow health secretary and one of Mr Corbyn’s closest allies, did not take part in the vote after suffering a migraine. Result | Vote on the Brexit bill 
T hirty-three Labour MPs also voted in favour of an SNP amendment to “kill” Article 50 and effectively block Brexit. The motion was defeated with 100 MPs voting for it and 336 against. 
MPs voted by four to one in favour of triggering Article 50 and beginning the process of leaving the European Union. 
Boris Johnson, the Foreign Secretary, said that "history has been made" as he hailed the "momentous" result, with MPs voting 498 to 114 in favour. MPs who voted against triggering Article 50 
T heresa May will on Thursday table a white paper formally setting out her plans for Brexit in response to the concerns of pro-European MPs. 
There will be a further rebellion by Labour MPs next week as the Article 50 legislation reaches its third reading in the Commons. 
Labour has tabled seven amendments, including one which would force Mrs May to send the final terms of her deal back to Brussels if Parliament votes against them. Brexit Bill | How the major parties voted 
M r Corbyn tried to assert his authority by saying that Labour MPs had voted by more than three to one in favour of Article 50. He said: “Now the battle of the week ahead is to shape Brexit negotiations to put jobs, living standards and accountability centre stage. 
“Labour’s amendments are the real agenda. The challenge is for MPs of all parties to ensure the best deal for Britain, and that doesn’t mean giving Theresa May a free hand to turn Britain into a bargain basement tax haven.” Follow Telegraph News
